attributes.title: Do Perception of Candidate Competence and Empowerment Effects from Descriptive Representation Affect whether Voters Feel Subjectively Represented?

q1.value: Do Perception of Candidate Competence and Empowerment Effects from Descriptive Representation Affect whether Voters Feel Subjectively Represented?

q2.value: Dominik Duell | Sveinung Arnesen | Yvette Peters

q9.value: Hold out sample: Registration after analysis of sample 1 (outcome data from 4 countries: Island, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden) but prior to analysis of sample 2 (outcome data from 2 countries: France, Germany)

q15.value: In paired conjoint experiments embedded in surveys in six European countries, France, Germany, Iceland, Netherlands, Norway, and Sweden, we elicit which hypothetical candidate, as characterized by a set of social traits, voters see themselves closest to in political views (closeness treatment) and, then, which candidate they would actually prefer to see in office (voteChoice treatment). This is a between-subject design. Candidates vary in age, education, gender, religion, or class. We already collected observations on Iceland, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden (Sample 1) but provide a hold-out sample 2 (data from the same experiment in France and Germany) to demonstrate the robustness of our findings. Data for these samples are collected but not published yet, i.e., we do not have access to this data, yet.

q16.value: We test (1) Subjective representation hypothesis: there is a close match between the effect of the list of candidate attributes on decisions in closeness and vote choice. (2) Competence hypothesis: respondents have a preference for male, middle-aged, highly educated candidates even when they feel closer in their views to a candidate characterized by a different set of attributes. (3) Empowerment hypothesis: respondents whose in-group acknowledges the empowering effect of descriptive representation, prefer in-group candidates over those they feel themselves close to in terms of political views.

q17.value: We estimate the (1) change in predicted probability of seeing a candidate being close in political views in the closeness treatment and the (2) change in predicted probability of preferring a candidate associated with a particular realization of a social attribute in the \textit{voteChoice} treatment (relative to a meaningful baseline). And, then, we compute a \textit{treatment effect} as the \textit{difference in average change between the sample of respondents that received the question about which candidate is closer in political views and the sample of respondents that received the question about which candidate they would prefer to see in office.

q18.value: France, Germany, Island, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden

attributes.title: By What Authority? Uncovering The Conditional Mandate from Referendums in EU Membership Decisions

q1.value: By What Authority? Uncovering The Conditional Mandate from Referendums in EU Membership Decisions

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: A virtue of democratic decision-making procedures is that the foundations in which decisions are made are thought to enhance the legitimacy of the decision. Decisions made by, and for the people are thought to make the citizens likely to willingly comply with the outcome. We study the nuances of this assumption and ask under what conditions democratic decisions are seen as legitimate in the eyes of the people. Specifically, we investigate what mandate citizens award an EU membership referendum in three European non-member and three member countries based on the level of turnout, size of majority, and favorability of the outcome. Arguably, the use of referendums may enhance public support for democracy in a time when “critical citizens” demand new alternative forms of political participation. The direct link between the citizens' preferences and the decision-outcome is an important property of referendums, and different forms of direct democratic initiatives have grown in popularity in contemporary Europe. Indeed, European integration issues of membership, key policies, endorsement of treaties and constitutional documents are the most voted-on issue in the world. There is thus a need to investigate when people perceive referendum results as legitimate decision outcomes. Utilizing a conjoint experimental design, we proposed to a representative sample of Norwegian citizens an imagined scenario where European Union membership was put out for a referendum. They were given different scenarios, where turnout level, size of majority, and outcome are varied; three critical dimensions that always will be present in any referendum. Do people think that the government should follow any result once the issue is decided on in a referendum, or do they change opinion when learning about the attributes of the specific referendum? The point of departure is the assumption that people think the results of a referendum on EU membership should be followed, regardless of the turnout level, size of majority, and the outcome of the referendum itself. By varying these three attributes of a referendum, the share of citizens that think the result should be followed by the government spanned from virtually everyone to only a quarter of the population. The results also showed an interaction between outcome favorability and majority size: When the majority size was small, the voters who saw an unfavorable outcome were less likely to accept the referendum than those who saw an unfavorable outcome were. Furthermore, the outcome favorability effect was moderated by membership attitudes: Those who were against EU-membership were significantly less likely to approve of a referendum with an unfavorable outcome than the pro-EU voters were. In a second fielding of the experiment, we are currently gathering data from six European countries. The experiment is part of the 2017 EIPS survey wave, which consists of six European academically run panels. The recruitment strategy of the panels ensures that all citizens have a close to equal, non-zero, likelihood of being invited to participate, ensuring high quality samples representative of the populations of the respective countries. We have received the results from Norway, Iceland, Sweden, and The Netherlands. The findings so far reveal similar main effects across these four countries. In all countries, the outcome favorability effect is moderated by membership attitudes: Anti-EU respondents in Non-EU member countries are significantly more negative to a "Yes"-outcome than pro-EU respondents are to a "No"-outcome (Iceland and Norway. Reversely in member countries, pro-EU respondents are significantly more negative to "No"-outcome than anti-EU respondents are to a "Yes"-outcome (The Netherlands and Norway). The motivation for registering the study now is to provide out-of-sample data from Germany and France to test whether the results revealed so far hold when tested against hold-out samples.

q16.value: Our six hypotheses are: 1) The lower the turnout, the less likely a referendum result is to be considered as a mandate for making a political decision 2) The smaller the majority, the less likely a referendum result is to be considered as a mandate for making a political decision 3) An outcome that is unfavorable to a voter, makes the voter less likely to consider the referendum result as a mandate for making a political decision 4) The outcome favorability effect is moderated by outcome preferences of the voters: Voters who prefer the status quo outcome are less likely to accept an unfavorable referendum outcome as a mandate for making a political decision than are voters who prefer change. 5) There is an interaction effect between outcome favorability and majority size: When the majority size is small, the voters who receive an unfavorable outcome are less likely to consider the referendum as a mandate for making a political decision than those who receive a favorable outcome are. 6) There is an interaction effect between outcome favorability and turnout: When turnout is low, the voters who receive an unfavorable outcome are less likely to consider the referendum as a mandate for making a political decision than those who receive a favorable outcome are.

q17.value: Following Hainmueller, Hopkins and Yamamoto (2014), we estimate the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE) to estimate the treatment effects.

q18.value: France, Germany, The Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, and Iceland

q27.value: Researchers, The European Internet Panel Study (EIPS); a consortium of European academically run survey panels (Sciences Po, Mannheim University, Tilburg University, University of Bergen, University of Gothenburg, University of Iceland)

q31.value: All results that do not violate privacy laws in the respective countries can be published

attributes.title: Shaping elite attitudes towards peace agreements: Do citizens' preferences matter?

q1.value: Shaping elite attitudes towards peace agreements: Do citizens' preferences matter?

q2.value: Natalia Garbiras Diaz | Miguel Garcia-Sanchez | Aila Matanock

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In this project, we seek to study how legislators form their opinions about peace processes and their provisions. Colombia recently signed and approved a peace agreement with FARC. A well-known NGO in Colombia, called Misión de Observación Electoral, surveyed the universe of Colombian legislators (n=280) and asked about their political attitudes about a wide array of topics, including postconflict. They agreed to allow us to include a survey experiment (in the form of a vignette) to study how members of Congress respond to information about citizens' attitudes and preferences towards the Colombian peace agreement. In particular, we randomized whether legislators were shown or not a small vignette that told them what is the percentage of citizens in Colombia who support the reservation of 16 special seats in the lower chamber, to give more representation to areas of the country most affected by civil conflict. Notice that this provision is already included in the legislative agenda and is currently being discussed in Congress. NO deception was used. The data that we provided comes from the LAPOP surveys, a public opinion survey coordinated by Vanderbilt University that has been conducted in the Americas since 2004. We use data from the 2016 and 2017 waves. Thus, all information provided to legislators is true and accurate, and included the source.

q16.value: (response to this field was provided on January 23, 2019) In this project, we study two sets of questions. The first one studies misperceptions about average public support for one of the provisions included in the peace agreement signed between FARC and the Colombian government, among members of Congress. Specifically, we seek to characterize those misperceptions (from a descriptive point of view) and explore their magnitude across subgroups. We expect: - legislators will estimate a larger support for the proposal among citizens living in conflict areas than among the overall population. - legislators coming from (representing) areas that have experienced higher intensity of civil conflict or from areas expected to benefit from this provision to have more information about the preferences of their citizens than other legislators and thus have more accurate priors of citizens' preferences. - legislators from parties that have previously opposed the peace agreement (or specifically this policy) to underestimate its support among Colombians, expecting evidence that confirms their stance. - legislators from parties that have previously supported the peace agreement (or this proposal) to overestimate its support among Colombians Second, we assess the extent to which information about citizens' preferences shapes congressional members' support for the policies. Here, we present some preliminary hypotheses about which congressional members are likely to use data on support from the overall population, from citizens living in conflict areas, or not to use these data when taking a position on the policy: - Congressional members with more votes from municipalities that would benefit from these special seats should be more likely to prioritize information coming from the sample of residents of conflict zones than from the overall population. In general, they should be more likely to use the information. - Congressional members who place post-conflict as one of the top three priorities of the legislative agenda for the period 2018-2022 should be more likely to use the information about citizens' preferences, regardless of the sample where it comes from. - Congressional members belonging to parties who oppose to the peace agreement or tend to have negative attitudes towards it, will be less likely to use any type of information. However, information about the sample of Colombians should have a larger effect on this group.

q27.value: NGO called Misión de Observarción Electoral

attributes.title: Coercion and the Credibility of Assurances

q1.value: Coercion and the Credibility of Assurances

q2.value: Matthew Cebul | Nuno Monteiro | Allan Dafoe

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This study (as described in the attached prospectus) employs a survey experiment involving a hypothetical conflict between the United States and China to explore the determinants of successful international coercion. Much of the literature on international crisis bargaining focuses on threat credibility as the key factor underlying successful coercion, and explores the mechanisms by which states can credibly signal their resolve to their opponents. In contrast, we emphasize that credible assurances against future punishment, should the target comply with the challenger's demand, are just as important to coercion: if the target anticipates that the challenger will enact its threat regardless of the target's behavior, then the target has little incentive to comply with the demand. We use a hypothetical crisis scenario in an online survey of U.S. citizens to investigate the factors that determine the credibility of a challenger's assurances against future punishment, including power and a reputation for restraint.

q16.value: Our main hypothesis is that the likelihood of successful coercion increases with assurance credibility. We also test hypotheses regarding the determinants of assurance credibility: we believe that assurance credibility will increase when the challenger also has a reputation for restraint, but will decrease when the challenger is relatively powerful.

q17.value: Our crisis vignette describes a hypothetical conflict between the U.S. and China, in which China demands that the U.S. recognize its sovereignty over the Diaoyu Islands. Respondents are told that they are U.S. foreign policy advisors, and asked questions about how they would react to the crisis. We randomly manipulate China's relative power and it's reputation for restraint, our two key independent variables. We then ask respondents questions about China's Threat and Assurance Credibility, and also ask respondents how Resolved they are to resist China's demands. With these dependent variables collected, simple difference-in-means tests will be employed to determine the effect of our manipulations on each dependent variable. We will also use linear regression to improve the efficiency of those estimates, controlling for a battery of demographic variables. Standard errors will be bootstrapped.

attributes.title: Perception of Mobility and Trust in Government: An Experimental Approach

q1.value: Perception of Mobility and Trust in Government: An Experimental Approach

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: According to the “prospect of upward mobility hypothesis,” the poor may not support redistribution that involves taxing the rich with the expectation of becoming rich in the future (Benabou and Ok 2001). Given the steep decline in absolute mobility in the past four decades (Chetty et al. 2017), then, one would expect an increase in support for redistribution. However, the redistributive preference has not budged (Kuziemko et al. 2015). On this puzzle, Alesina et al. (2017) test whether providing a pessimistic information on intergenerational mobility to respondents increase their support for redistribution. While they find a significant causal effect, the right-wing respondents still did not change their redistributive preference despite adopting more pessimistic views on mobility. The authors point to the government as the culprit; the conservatives may perceive the government as the cause of the low mobility, hence do not support redistribution administered by the government. Is it true that people blame and exhibit low trust in the government for the decline in mobility? If so, would the converse – a more optimistic view on social mobility increasing trust in government – hold? Building on Alesina et al. (2017), we plan to establish a more robust causal relationship between perception of mobility and trust in government through a survey experiment. Please see the attached "Prospectus and Bibliography" document for the proper bibliography.

q16.value: In addition to establishing the causal relationship between perception of mobility and trust in government, we plan to extend the research on this topic by further exploring the consequences of higher (lower) public trust. Specifically, we test whether the increased (decreased) trust in government resulting from being exposed one of our perception of mobility treatments leads to higher (lower) voting participation plan in the upcoming 2018 General Election. With such an objective, this experiment will test the following hypotheses: 1) Perception of mobility is positively correlated with people's trust in government. 2) Trust in government plays a mediating role determining the perception of mobility; treatment effects on perception of mobility differ by respondents' perception of trustworthiness of the government. 3) Treatments that affect respondents' perception of mobility positively (negatively) leads to higher (lower) trust in government. 4) Lower (higher) trust in government leads to lower (higher) voting participation plan.

q17.value: We will address the hypotheses listed above using a simple experiment where respondents are assigned to one of six groups, resulting from 2 X 3 design. On one dimension, respondents are assigned to either seeing the "trust in government" questions pre or post-treatment. On another dimension, respondents are assigned to one of three groups: control, positive, and negative treatment groups. Positive and negative treatments refer to the positive and negative information treatments designed to affect respondents' perception of mobility in the U.S.

attributes.title: Monitoring Corruption and Overcoming the Collective Action Problem

q1.value: Monitoring Corruption and Overcoming the Collective Action Problem

q2.value: Michael Denly | Mobin Piracha | Adityamohan Tantravahi

q5.value: For advice or feedback, we thank Mike Findley, Michael Gibbs, Xiaobo Lu, Megan Farrell, and Scott Wolford. All errors are those of the authors.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Recently, scholars have disputed the notion that monitoring can help overcome corruption. Meanwhile, development institutions have used more results-based financing that obviates the need to monitor corruption as well. In light of these challenges to the utility of the principal-agent framework, this article asks: Does monitoring crowd out or contribute to collective action against corruption? To answer this question, we formally model corruption as a collective action problem and propose related lab-in-the-field experiments in India, Pakistan, and the United States. Our model suggests that the collective benefits of monitoring generally do not help with shifting to lower corruption equilibria. However, the individual benefits of monitoring are high and aggregate quickly, suggesting that monitoring indirectly contributes to collective action in the long run but not the short run. This pre-analysis plan details what we expect to find and how we will conduct our lab-in-the-field experiments.

q16.value: Monitoring, particularly higher amounts of it, will lead participants to converge more frequently on the social optimum (cooperate, cooperate)—that is, for our lab-in-the-field experiments that conceptualize corruption as a collective action problem and closely mimic the classic prisoner’s dilemma game.

q17.value: We will test our hypotheses through lab-in-the-field experiments.

registration_responses.q15: Recently, scholars have disputed the notion that monitoring can help overcome corruption. Meanwhile, development institutions have used more results-based financing that obviates the need to monitor corruption as well. In light of these challenges to the utility of the principal-agent framework, this article asks: Does monitoring crowd out or contribute to collective action against corruption? To answer this question, we formally model corruption as a collective action problem and propose related lab-in-the-field experiments in India, Pakistan, and the United States. Our model suggests that the collective benefits of monitoring generally do not help with shifting to lower corruption equilibria. However, the individual benefits of monitoring are high and aggregate quickly, suggesting that monitoring indirectly contributes to collective action in the long run but not the short run. This pre-analysis plan details what we expect to find and how we will conduct our lab-in-the-field experiments.
registration_responses.q16: Monitoring, particularly higher amounts of it, will lead participants to converge more frequently on the social optimum (cooperate, cooperate)—that is, for our lab-in-the-field experiments that conceptualize corruption as a collective action problem and closely mimic the classic prisoner’s dilemma game.
registration_responses.q17: We will test our hypotheses through lab-in-the-field experiments.

attributes.title: Mobilizing the Law in Authoritarian Societies: Lawful Resistance in Egypt, Jordan and Palestine

q1.value: Mobilizing the Law in Authoritarian Societies: Lawful Resistance in Egypt, Jordan and Palestine

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In the MENA countries, law is generally more deferential to state prerogatives than it is protective of citizens’ rights. And states throughout the Middle East often disregard the rule of law entirely. Under what conditions will people use law as a tool for challenging states that operate above the law? And what is the relationship between challenging the state through litigation and other methods of grievance pursuit, such as collective action and petitioning elites? I will address these questions through four survey experiments in Egypt and Jordan. The first set of surveys (1 Egypt, 1 Jordan) will treat respondents with varying information on state (dis)unity. The second set of surveys (1 Egypt, 1 Jordan) will treat respondents with varying information on judicial deference/activism. I will also explore potential mediating and moderating effects of three factors: (1) perceptions of judicial independence; (2) support for the sitting government; and (3) beliefs on the relative power of central versus local state actors.

q16.value: H1a : Information on state disunity increases the propensity for individuals to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation. H1b : Information on state unity decreases the propensity for individuals to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation. H1c : Individuals who receive information on state disunity are more willing to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation than individuals who receive information on state unity. H2a : Information on state disunity decreases individuals’ willingness to protest specifically by increasing their willingness to pursue grievances against the state through litigation. H2b : Information on state unity increases individuals’ willingness to protest specifically by decreasing their willingness to pursue grievances against the state through litigation. H3a : Individuals who receive the state unity treatment will be more willing to protest than those who receive the control treatment. H3b : Individuals who receive the state unity treatment will be more willing to protest than those who receive the state disunity treatment. H4a : Information on state disunity has a stronger (positive) effect on the propensity of litigation among individuals who have lower evaluations of judicial independence. H4b : Information on state unity has a stronger (negative) effect on the propensity of litigation among individuals who have lower evaluations of judicial independence H5 : Information on state disunity has a greater effect on the propensity of litigation among individuals who believe that central state actors are more powerful than local state actors. H6 : Information on state disunity has a greater effect on the propensity of litigation among individuals who have higher levels of support for the government. H7 : Information on state disunity has a weaker effect on the propensity of litigation among people who live in rural areas. H8 : Information on state disunity has a greater effect on the propensity of litigation among people with higher incomes. H9a : Information on state disunity increases the propensity for individuals to pursue their grievances against the state by petitioning the governor. H9b : Information on state unity decreases the propensity for individuals to pursue their grievances against the state by petitioning the governor. H9c : Individuals who receive information on state disunity are more willing to pursue their grievances against the state by petitioning the governor than individuals who receive information on state unity. H10a : Information on judicial decisions in favor of the government decreases the propensity for individuals to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation. H10b : Information on judicial decisions against the government increases the propensity for individuals to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation. H10c : Individuals who receive information on judicial decisions against the government are more willing to pursue litigation against the state than individuals who receive information on judicial decisions in favor of the government. H11a : Information on judicial verdicts against the government decreases individuals’ willingness to protest specifically by increasing their willingness to pursue grievances against the state through litigation. H11b : Information on judicial verdicts in favor of the government increases individuals’ willingness to protest specifically by decreasing their willingness to pursue grievances against the state through litigation. H12a : Information on recent judicial verdicts against the government increases the propensity for individuals to pursue litigation against the state specifically by increasing the extent to which they believe that the judiciary is independent. H12b : Information on recent judicial verdicts in favor of the government decreases the propensity for individuals to pursue litigation against the state specifically by decreasing the extent to which they believe that the judiciary is independent. H13a : Information on recent judicial verdicts against the government increases individuals’ evaluations of judicial independence. H13b : Information on recent judicial verdicts in favor of the government decreases individuals’ evaluations of judicial independence. H13c : Individuals who receive information on judicial verdicts in favor of the government will have lower evaluations of judicial independence than individuals who receive information on judicial verdicts against the government. H14 : Information on judicial verdicts against the government has a greater effect on the propensity of litigation among people who have lower levels of support for the government. H15 : Information on judicial verdicts against the government has a weaker effect on the propensity of litigation among people who live in rural areas. H16 : Information on state disunity has a greater effect on the propensity of litigation among people with higher incomes. H17 : Individuals who pursue their grievances against the state through litigation are less likely to pursue their grievances against the state through protest. H18a : Individuals with higher levels of support for the government are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation. H18b: Individuals with higher levels of support for the government are less likely to pursue their grievances against the state through protest. H19a : Individuals who are willing pursue their grievances against the state through litigation are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state through protest. H19b : Individuals who are willing pursue their grievances against the state through litigation are more likely to pursue their grievances through petitioning. H19c : Individuals who are willing pursue their grievances against the state through protest are more likely to pursue their grievances through petitioning. H20a : Individuals who perceive higher levels of judicial independence are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation. H20b : The (positive) effect of perceptions of judicial independence on the likelihood of litigation is greater among people with higher levels of support for the government. H21 : Individuals who perceive higher levels of judicial independence are less likely to pursue their grievances against the state through protest. H21a : The (negative) effect of perceptions of judicial independence on the likelihood of protest is greater among people with higher levels of support for the government. H22 : Individuals with higher perceptions of judicial independence are less likely to protest specifically because they are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state through litigation. H23 : Individuals who support the government are more likely to view the judiciary as independent. H24 : Individuals with higher levels of government support are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state by petitioning the governor. H25 : Individuals who believe that local state actors are more powerful that central state actors are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state by petitioning the governor. H26 : Individuals living in rural areas are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state by petitioning the governor. H27 : Individuals with higher incomes are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state by petitioning the governor H28 : Individuals who pursue their grievances against the state through litigation are more willing to petition the governor than individuals who pursue their grievances against the state through protest. H29: Individuals with higher incomes are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state through legal channels. H30 : Individuals who are employed are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state through legal channels than individuals who are unemployed. H31 : Individuals living in urban areas are more likely to pursue their grievances against the state through legal channels than individuals who live in rural areas. H32 : Individuals who believe that central state actors are more powerful than local state actors are more likely to pursue litigation. H33 : Individuals who believe that central state actors are more powerful than local state actors are more likely to protest.

q17.value: I will test these hypotheses using regression analysis. Models estimating treatment effects will first be run excluding control variables. To check for robustness, I will subsequently conduct the regression analyses including appropriate controls. All hypotheses on conditional effects and heterogeneous treatment effects will be analyzed using interaction terms. All hypotheses on mediating variable will be tested using causal mediation analysis.

q19.value: Egypt Disunity Survey (n=1,000); Egypt Activism Survey (n=1,000); Jordan Disunity Survey (n=500); Jordan Activism Survey (n=500)

attributes.title: Self- and Virtue-Signaling in an Age of Polarization: Activating Political Identity to Distinguish Oneself and Affirm a Positive Self-Image

q1.value: Self- and Virtue-Signaling in an Age of Polarization: Activating Political Identity to Distinguish Oneself and Affirm a Positive Self-Image

q5.value: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Political Science Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (PS DDRIG) No. 1647425. , I also acknowledge the excellent research assistance of Arusyak Hakhnazaryan and funding support from the Center for Experimental Social Science at New York University for piloting of this project. , I received valuable comments from Kevin Arceneaux, Delia Baldassarri, Alexa Bankert, Eric Dickson, Patrick Egan, Rebecca Morton, Jonathan Woon, and participants at the 2017 SPSA Conference and 2017 Toronto Political Behaviour Workshop. , The author takes credit for all errors.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Visit any online media platform today and one will find individuals expressing their political opinions. This project is driven by two research questions. First, what motivates people to engage in online political expression? Second, are the determinants of online political expression different from those underlying online non-political expression? I hypothesize that one reason online settings are desirable venues for expression is because they allow individuals to cheaply secure a positive self-image. My second hypothesis concerns political expression more narrowly: I hypothesize that individuals choose to engage in online political expression in order to affirm their ownership of desired traits that they associate with their political in-group – or alternatively to affirm that they do not possess non-desired attributes associated with a political out-group identity.

q16.value: In my pre-analysis plan, I specify 7 hypotheses, their empirical implications, and how I plan to test them in my study (see table 8). As noted above, my first specified hypothesis is that individuals engage in low-cost expression to a) confirm their identity and b) ownership (non-ownership) of identity-consistent (inconsistent) traits and c) through doing so, to obtain an improved self-image. My second hypothesis is that partisans engage in low-cost political expression to a) confirm their partisan identity and b) ownership (non-ownership) of in- (out-) group partisan-associated traits and c) through doing so, to obtain an improved self-image. My primary outcome is individuals’ demand for low-cost expression, and I will evaluate how this demand changes based on feedback on partisan-associated and non-associated trait ownership.

q17.value: I will conduct an online experiment wherein subjects are randomly assigned to receive different feedback on their ownership of partisan-associated and non-associated traits and then they will have the option to “pay” to express themselves politically or non-politically. See the pre-analysis plan for more.

attributes.title: Do Scandals Matter? An Conjoint Experiment in the U.K.

q1.value: Do Scandals Matter? An Conjoint Experiment in the U.K.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In this project, I test whether scandals will affect how voters choose politicians. Based on the theory of valence issue, scandals should be a source of political information on which voters rely on. Through the conjoint experimental design, this project will examine whether subjects dislike politicians who are involved in scandals while they also observe these politicians' personal characteristics, including their partisan affiliation and policy position.

q16.value: Main Effect H1: Voters prefer politicians who are not involved in salient scandals. H2: Voters dislike politicians whose coalition partner is involved in salient scandals, even though the politicians are not involved in scandals (spill-over effect). H3: Voters dislike prime ministers whose minister is involved in salient scandals, even though the prime ministers are not involved in scandals (bottom-up effect). H4: Voters dislike ministers whose prime minister is involved in salient scandals, even though the ministers are not involved in scandals (top-down effect). Heterogeneous Effect H5: The effect of salient scandals is conditional on the level of politicians, i.e. candidates, ministers, and prime minister. H6: The effect of salient scandals is conditional on both politicians' and subjects' partisan affiliation. H7: The effect of salient scandals is conditional on both politicians' and subjects' policy position. H8: When subjects see their preferred politicians (based on other characteristics) are involved in salient scandals, their answering time will be delayed.

q17.value: This project will conduct a conjoint experiment to examine whether voters respond to scandals in the U.K. This experiment will be conducted with the assistance of ESSEXLab. In this experiment, each subject will be asked to choose the preferred politician from the two tasks based on their attributes, including gender, party, position on EU integration, scandal status, and external conditions (detailed in the attached file). Each subject will be asked to make choices for three separate sections, for choosing preferred candidates, preferred prime ministers, and preferred ministers separately, and each section contains five rounds. At the end stage of the experiment, each subject will be asked to provide his/her demographical information, such as age, party affiliation and strength, gender, education level, and position on EU integration and strength.

attributes.title: Response Bias as a Consequence of Incentives or Altruism in Invitations to Participate

q1.value: Response Bias as a Consequence of Incentives or Altruism in Invitations to Participate

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Response bias has been shown to exist within surveys and as a consequence of non-response to surveys in the methodological survey literature (Groves 2006; Massey and Tourangeau 2012; Kulas et al. 2017). Likewise, various invitation forms and strategies (e.g., monetary incentives, advance letters, sponsorship, social proof and telephone or SMS follow-up) have been tested in order to increase response rates (Singer et al. 2000; Hansen and Pedersen 2012; Pedersen and Nielsen 2016). However, less attention has been given to the interaction between response bias and the particular research topics investigated in the surveys. As some topics may correlate heavily with the propensity to participate in surveys, response bias may have large consequences for the conclusions drawn from these surveys. This tendency may be exacerbated by the now common practices of offering incentives or appeal to altruistic motives to increase the response rate (Hansen and Pedersen 2012). A case in point is public service motivation (Perry and Wise 1990). Public service motivation can be described as ‘an individual’s orientation to delivering services to people with a purpose to do good for others and society’ (Perry and Hondeghem 2008, p.vii) and is typically described as a particular aspect of altruism, which is tied to the delivery of public services. A fundamental expectation in the theory is that public service motivated individuals are attracted by altruistic opportunities but repelled by economic incentives, which can crowd out the intrinsic value of a contribution (Perry & Wise 1990). It is obvious that some of the theoretical antecedents of public service motivation are also antecedents of survey participation – if not directly, then by extension. Asking a professional to give some time to answering a survey that will contribute to science clearly speaks to altruism, while offering a monetary incentive instead speaks to the opposite: extrinsic motivation (Ryan and Deci 2000). If invitations to participate in research surveys use these quite different appeals they might create a selection process that also ends up affecting public service motivation: participants initially reacting to a monetary incentive may have lower public service motivation, while participants reacting to an altruistic message may have higher public service motivation on average. Ultimately, such biases can threaten the ability to draw conclusions, which are valid for a general population of people. Selection into a survey may be exacerbated further by (planned or unplanned) framing effects within the survey (Chong and Druckman 2007). Such context effects are common in surveys (Schwarz and Strack 1991; Hjortskov 2017), and they may affect the final outcome measures as well. That is, besides the selection effects that may be caused by the method of inviting participants into surveys, framing effects within the survey may obscure the final attitude measure (for example a public service motivation measure) further. Literature Chong, D., Druckman, J.N. (2007) ‘Framing Theory’, Annual Review of Political Science, 10(1), 103–126. Groves, R.M. (2006) ‘Nonresponse Rates and Nonresponse Bias in Household Surveys’, The Public Opinion Quarterly, 70(5), 646–675. Hansen, K.M., Pedersen, R.T. (2012) ‘Efficiency of different recruitment strategies for web panels’, International Journal of Public Opinion Research, 24(2), 238–249. Hjortskov, M. (2017) ‘Priming and Context Effects in Citizen Satisfaction Surveys’, Online access in Public Administration, available: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/padm.12346/full. Jensen, U.T., Andersen, L.B. (2015) ‘Public Service Motivation, User Orientation, and Prescription Behaviour: Doing Good for Society or for the Individual User?’, Public Administration, 93(3), 753–768. Kjeldsen, A.M., Jacobsen, C.B. (2013) ‘Public Service Motivation and Employment Sector: Attraction or Socialization?’, Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory, 23(4), 899–926. Kulas, J.T., Robinson, D.H., Kellar, D.Z., Smith, J.A. (2017) ‘Nonresponse in Organizational Surveying: Attitudinal Distribution Form and Conditional Response Probabilities’ Impact on Patterns of Bias’, Public Opinion Quarterly, 81(2), 401–421. Massey, D.S., Tourangeau, R. (2012) The Nonresponse Challenge to Surveys and Statistics, SAGE. Pedersen, M.J., Nielsen, C.V. (2016) ‘Improving Survey Response Rates in Online Panels Effects of Low-Cost Incentives and Cost-Free Text Appeal Interventions’, Social Science Computer Review, 34(2), 229–243. Perry, J.L., Hondeghem, A. (2008) Motivation in Public Management: The Call of Public Service, Oxford University Press on Demand. Perry, J.L., Wise, L.R. (1990) ‘The Motivational Bases of Public Service’, Public Administration Review, 50(3), 367–373. Rainey, H.G. (1983) ‘Public Agencies and Private Firms: Incentive Structures, Goals, and Individual Roles’, Administration & Society, 15(2), 207–242. Ryan, R.M., Deci, E.L. (2000) ‘Self-determination theory and the facilitation of intrinsic motivation, social development, and well-being.’, American psychologist, 55(1), 68. Schwarz, N., Strack, F. (2000) ‘Experiments with Incentives in Telephone Surveys’, Public Opinion Quarterly, 64(2), 171–188. Vössing, K., Weber, T. (2017) ‘Information Behavior and Political Preferences’, British Journal of Political Science, 1–24. Wing, C., Clark, M.H. (2017) ‘What Can We Learn From A Doubly Randomized Preference Trial?—An Instrumental Variables Perspective’, Journal of Policy Analysis and Management, 36(2), 418–437.

q16.value: Primary hypothesis: H1: Invitations containing monetary incentives or altruistic messages will create larger response rates than a neutral invitation H2a: An invitation with a monetary incentive will result in less public service motivated survey participants than a neutral invitation H2b: An invitation with an altruistic invitation will result in more public service motivated survey participants than a neutral invitation Secondary hypotheses: H3: An altruistic reminder will result in more public service motivated survey participants than if no reminder is presented. This effect will be more pronounced among the participants who received the altruism invitation H4: A reminder of own job situation will result in less public service motivated survey participants than if no reminder is presented. This effect will be more pronounced among the participants who received the monetary incentive invitation H5a: Participants who have received the altruistic invitation will to a larger extent choose the altruistic frame in the choice reminder than the participants who have received the monetary incentive invitation or the neutral invitation H5b: Participants who have received the monetary incentive invitation will to a larger extent choose the self-centered frame in the choice reminder than the participants who have received the altruistic invitation or the neutral invitation H6a: The effect of the altruistic frame on the public service motivation index will be larger among the participants who are in the choice reminder and have actively selected the altruistic frame H6b: The effect of the self-centered frame on the public service motivation index will be larger among the participants who are in the choice reminder and have actively selected the self-centered frame H6c: The effects of the choice frames (H6a and H6b) will be largest within the corresponding invitation letter group

q17.value: Population The population is the Danish physiotherapists registered with the The Association of Danish Physiotherapists. There are around 10,000 physiotherapists registered with the association, and previous research have succeeded in an response rate of about 52-65 %, and if we can obtain similar response rates, we can expect between 5,200 and 6,500 answers. Our power calculations are based on the conservative guess of 3000 answers. The Association of Danish Physiotherapists organizes physiotherapists in both the private and the public sector as well as both employers and employees. Design The design consists of 3 different invitations and 4 different reminders that further seek to frame the public service motivation in an altruistic or self-centered way. Respondents are randomized into one of 12 possible groups receiving 1 one of three invitations and 1 of 3 types of reminders or no reminder. The 3 invitations are of the same length (298-302 words and 1577-1583 signs). All of them inform about the general purpose of the survey, some general information about the survey and the sender of it and ask for the physiotherapists’ participation. Apart from that, the first invitation has an altruistic frame, emphasizing the societal role of physiotherapists and in research that results in new knowledge about what motivates them. The second invitation contains a monetary incentive in the form of a price lottery, where it is possible to win 5 prizes of 3000 kr. (about 400 Euros or 470 American Dollars). The third invitation serves as a control invitation containing extra information about the general contents of the study without stressing any altruistic purposes or giving any incentives. The test of H1 is a simple difference-in-means of these three invitations on the response rate. After a very short introduction in the survey itself, the respondents will be directed through a set of background questions (e.g., gender, age, employment). After these questions, the reminders are introduced. There are 3 different reminders and a group not receiving any reminder. The 3 reminders all seek to frame the public service motivation questions in different ways (Chong and Druckman 2007), whereas the last group just receives the questions without any introduction. The first reminder will frame the public service motivation questions as asking about the societal and political role of the physiotherapists’ work. This reminder will therefore possibly interact with the respondents who were invited into the survey by the altruistic invitation. The second reminder will introduce the public service motivation questions as questions about their own role at their workplace. This reminder is designed to mostly interact with the respondents who had the incentive invitation. The third and last reminder is a combination of the two previous ones, asking the physiotherapists to choose between the framings of the public service motivation questions. The question asks them to choose between answering two different sets of questions: the societal and political role of their work or their own role at their workplace. No matter their choice, they will be asked the same set of public service motivation questions (steered selection (Vössing and Weber 2017)). This will give us an estimate of the physiotherapists’ selection into answering different questions about their work given their initial invitation into the survey. Power calculation A power calculation carried out in GPower 3.1 with a minimum detectable effect size of .25 shows that 250 respondents in each group will secure 80 pct. power (difference in independent means t-test assumed). Given our (conservatively) expected sample size of at least 3000 physiotherapists, the maximum number of groups becomes 12 (3000/12 = 250). Recruitment and randomization Recruitment to the online survey happens through The Association of Danish Physiotherapists’ registered e-mail addresses for their members. The randomization is simple random draws. Measurement Public service motivation is measured through a battery of validated items used in Jensen & Andersen (2015). Items reflecting all four conceptual dimensions of PSM – attraction to policy making, compassion, commitment to public interest, and self-sacrifice – were included and measured with 5-point Likert-type questions anchored at 1 representing ‘fully agree’ and 5 representing ‘fully disagree’. We treat PSM as an aggregate construct composed of all four sub-dimensions (2015, pp.759–760). Manipulation Checks I order to observe whether the different invitation letters succeeded in creating three different selection processes and group compositions a set of manipulation checks are employed. First, public employees have been shown to score higher on public service motivation (Rainey 1983; Kjeldsen and Jacobsen 2013). Therefore, we expect that publicly employed physiotherapists will to a larger degree select into the survey via the altruistic invitation letter, whereas the privately employed physiotherapists will have a larger tendency to select into the survey via the incentive invitation letter. Therefore, one manipulation check is whether sector of employment interacts with the treatments on the propensity to answer the survey (although the result also may have practical relevance). Second, after the outcome measure of public service motivation (and a large set of other, unrelated questions), we ask a set of direct altruism questions about donations to charitable giving and include a possibility to go to a specific charitable foundation’s homepage and donate (we track clicking on the link but not if they actually donate money). Pre-analysis plan The plan of analysis is first to apply the difference-in-means estimator via OLS regression and logistic regression to obtain the average treatment effect of the different invitation letters on the propensity to answer the survey (H1). OLS regression is also used to obtain the effect of the invitation letters on public service motivation (also difference-in-means) (H2a and H2b). H3 and H4 will both be analyzed as mean comparisons between combinations of the different groups (for example the altruistic invitation + altruistic reminder versus the monetary incentive invitation + reminder of own job situation) and interaction terms between invitations and reminders included in the OLS regressions on public service motivation. H5a and H5b will be analyzed with logistic regression with the choice of either the altruistic or the self-centered frame as the dependent variable. Lastly, H6a and H6b will be analyzed with the instrumental variables framework (Wing and Clark 2017). The randomization of the different frames (altruistic, self-centered, choice and none) will be used as an instrument on the choice of frame (which is non-random in nature) to compare the choice groups’ public service motivation with the public service motivation of the non-choice groups. Here, the two-stage least squares linear estimator will be employed. This analysis is also carried out within the corresponding invitation group (H6c). For example, among the participants, who were invited by the altruistic invitation the participants who choose the altruistic frame are compared to the participants who are shown the altruistic frame (without the choice option).

registration_responses.q1: Response Bias as a Consequence of Incentives or Altruism in Invitations to Participate
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Response bias has been shown to exist within surveys and as a consequence of non-response to surveys in the methodological survey literature (Groves 2006; Massey and Tourangeau 2012; Kulas et al. 2017). Likewise, various invitation forms and strategies (e.g., monetary incentives, advance letters, sponsorship, social proof and telephone or SMS follow-up) have been tested in order to increase response rates (Singer et al. 2000; Hansen and Pedersen 2012; Pedersen and Nielsen 2016). However, less attention has been given to the interaction between response bias and the particular research topics investigated in the surveys. As some topics may correlate heavily with the propensity to participate in surveys, response bias may have large consequences for the conclusions drawn from these surveys. This tendency may be exacerbated by the now common practices of offering incentives or appeal to altruistic motives to increase the response rate (Hansen and Pedersen 2012). A case in point is public service motivation (Perry and Wise 1990). Public service motivation can be described as ‘an individual’s orientation to delivering services to people with a purpose to do good for others and society’ (Perry and Hondeghem 2008, p.vii) and is typically described as a particular aspect of altruism, which is tied to the delivery of public services. A fundamental expectation in the theory is that public service motivated individuals are attracted by altruistic opportunities but repelled by economic incentives, which can crowd out the intrinsic value of a contribution (Perry & Wise 1990). It is obvious that some of the theoretical antecedents of public service motivation are also antecedents of survey participation – if not directly, then by extension. Asking a professional to give some time to answering a survey that will contribute to science clearly speaks to altruism, while offering a monetary incentive instead speaks to the opposite: extrinsic motivation (Ryan and Deci 2000). If invitations to participate in research surveys use these quite different appeals they might create a selection process that also ends up affecting public service motivation: participants initially reacting to a monetary incentive may have lower public service motivation, while participants reacting to an altruistic message may have higher public service motivation on average. Ultimately, such biases can threaten the ability to draw conclusions, which are valid for a general population of people. Selection into a survey may be exacerbated further by (planned or unplanned) framing effects within the survey (Chong and Druckman 2007). Such context effects are common in surveys (Schwarz and Strack 1991; Hjortskov 2017), and they may affect the final outcome measures as well. That is, besides the selection effects that may be caused by the method of inviting participants into surveys, framing effects within the survey may obscure the final attitude measure (for example a public service motivation measure) further. (2006) ‘Nonresponse Rates and Nonresponse Bias in Household Surveys’, The Public Opinion Quarterly, 70(5), 646–675. Hansen, K.M., Pedersen, R.T. (2012) ‘Efficiency of different recruitment strategies for web panels’, International Journal of Public Opinion Research, 24(2), 238–249. Hjortskov, M. (2017) ‘Priming and Context Effects in Citizen Satisfaction Surveys’, Online access in Public Administration, available: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/padm.12346/full. Jensen, U.T., Andersen, L.B. (2015) ‘Public Service Motivation, User Orientation, and Prescription Behaviour: Doing Good for Society or for the Individual User?’, Public Administration, 93(3), 753–768. Kjeldsen, A.M., Jacobsen, C.B. (2013) ‘Public Service Motivation and Employment Sector: Attraction or Socialization?’, Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory, 23(4), 899–926. Kulas, J.T., Robinson, D.H., Kellar, D.Z., Smith, J.A.
